text:
In this video, you’ll see how to execute automations 
on AWS resources from Jira Service Management.

Using the AWS Service Management Connector, 
you can integrate AWS Systems Manager with

Atlassian Jira Service Management, 
and then allow end users to execute

SSM Automation documents from 
Jira to perform common maintenance,

deployment, and remediation
tasks on AWS services.

We’ll begin by navigating to the AWS Service 
Management Connector to set up the integration.

For demonstration purposes, we’ve 
already connected a couple of AWS accounts.
Let’s view the Connector settings.

In the list of Connector features to enable, AWS 
System Manager Automation is already selected.
Let’s take a look at its configuration.
At least one Jira group must be specified.

We’ve already added a Jira 
group, so let’s save our settings.

Now that the integration is 
set up, let’s open a project.

Here we see the open 
tickets related to this project.

To perform remediations, we can use 
Systems Manager Automation documents.

Let’s go to the AWS Service 
Connector and select one.

Automation documents execute 
commands based on rules.

Let’s find one that allows us to 
restart an Amazon EC2 instance.

In this case, all we need to do is enter the 
ID of the EC2 instance we want to restart.
Tags are optional.
Let’s execute the automation.

When an automation is executed, 
a ticket is automatically created
for it in Jira Service Management.
The automation can take a few minutes to process.
From the ticket, we can review the execution details.
We can also view the steps of the execution.
We can dig further and view details for each step.

In the right panel, “execution completed” indicates that 
the Automation document processed successfully.

You’ve just seen how to execute 
automations on AWS resources
from Jira Service Management.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it’s your turn to try.
